Fields.DialogueText: ... And so, the little red hen, her loaf of bread taken from her, walked along the the shore, searching for anything to fill the bellies of her hungry chicks. She came upon the little gray seal.
Hold that still, while I get this back onto the wheel...
Yes, Comrade Kommuna.
... There. "Oh little grey seal, why do you weep?"
"I weep for I fear I shall never see my mother again. The blue cat wants fish but does not want to wet her feet, so she orders my mother to sea to catch them."
"The waters are full of cruel killer whales, and she has been gone too long..."
*smiles proudly*
There! That's the last one for now, I'm afraid.
Aww...
But what about the story, Comrade Kommuna?

Fields.MenuText: Yes, Parizhskaya Kommuna. Don't leave them in suspense.
What happens next is that the wicked captain takes the storytelling battleship away because it's past her naptime.
Hasn't she told that one about a half dozen times already?

Fields.DialogueText: Da, that would be cruel. But I am curious what you all think should happen next, so I will let you think about that until we next meet. I'll finish the story then.
That is not what happens next, because the storytelling battleship does not have a set naptime.
I was just getting to the good part, when the little red hen meets the working beasts and they can unite against their oppressors, Kapitan. Ah, well.
That reminds me... I have made all these bicycle repairs. Who will help me test them?
I will! I will!
That's the spirit! Be thorough, and tell me what you think later.
Thank you, Comrade Kommuna!
Once I have put away these tools and cleaned my hands, I will prepare for departure, Kapitan.
You knew?
Of the call? Only when the radio received it.
You didn't have to break your party up quite so soon, Comrade Kommuna. The boilers are still working up steam, and it'll take time to gather the crew back up.
The boilers I can assist with. As for the crew not on board, Pompa Petrenko was just here and I asked him to spread the word.
Was that wise? In front of your audience?
I merely noted that I was out of the cranberry extract I like to add to kvass, and that I was hoping he could find some for me.
Looks like you have everything under control.
No, Kapitan. If I did, the Neizvestniy flot would no longer be a menace.
@BATTLE
*yawns* Still, this would be a good place as any for an intermission. I will resume the tale another time.
Captain. First Comrade. Captain, a word...
You have my ear, Chief Engineer Dmitrieff.
We left port too soon, Captain.
I'm not sure I understand, Chief. I thought your people were some of the first to report back. Did we leave someone behind?
No one was left behind, Kapitan. Chief Dmitrieff's staff were among the first to return... I think because they were taking a break from boiler maintenance and had not gone far.
I wouldn't let them. What I mean is that some of our supplies hadn't arrived yet, so we didn't get them before our early departure.

Fields.MenuText: You mean there was work was being done aboard ship, but you still went and pursued bicycle research on the dock? I'm impressed, Parizhskaya.
Sorry, Chief, but between leaving before extra equipment arrives or leaving too late to stop some marauding Morganas, I'm going to choose the former every single time.
Engineering is your problem not mine, Chief. Make do without.

Fields.DialogueText: I would like to accept your compliment, Kapitan, but I'm afraid I can't. Boiler work is one of those tasks where space is limited.
I do not think she was asking you to make that choice.
I apologize, Kapitan, but there are some supplies that can't be worked around. Chief Dmitrieff will need those things eventually, or her problem will become yours as well.
We were supposed to get more fire bricks in. Luckily, I had enough bricks on hand to finish the boilers we started...
I believe she means wisely she didn't begin a project that could not be finished, even if we went to sea.
Hush, you. With Grey Horse's help here, I had the two of them ready and all boilers on line to give you maximum speed at your order.
... An order you will probably be giving again soon, Kapitan.
@BATTLE
I take up too much room to effectively help and Chief Dmitrieff chased me off for hovering.
Grey Horse is right, Kapitan.
Captain...
I win.
What was the wager?
That you would be on the bridge within five minutes of the Kapitan's latest orders.
You don't get hit in the nose for asking. As I was saying, Captain, navigation may not be my area of expertise, but I know when orders don't have us in the direction we came from.
Our firebricks should have arrived in port by now, and I can't stress their importance enough, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: Call it a brief detour, Chief.
I will engage the enemy at every opportunity, Chief. You should know that by now.
I understand. But as chaotic as Morganas are, they have to be pursued when found. We have a duty to chase her, Chief. We're the only ones in the area who can.

Fields.DialogueText: For a mad dog, seven miles is not a long detour. I'll believe it's a brief detour when I see it, Captain.
I do, now. That is my problem, Captain... had I grasped that sooner, I would have scheduled individual overhauls as a matter of course.
And it is my duty to provide maximum speed - without destroying the propulsion system - when you order it. At this rate, that is a duty I will be hard-pressed to carry out.
If it will allay your worries, Chief Dmitrieff, the Kapitan has put in an order for the replacement bricks to be loaded and brought to us via repair tender.
So not only can we still miss the bricks, but the bricks can miss us? You mean well, Grey Horse, but my concerns have just been compounded.
@BATTLE
Being given enough port time and resources to overhaul all the boilers at once? What was I thinking?
When I was told you had learned of a broken light and insisted on being the one to replace it, I thought it was a bad joke. But, here you are.
Mne zhal'. Should I have let you know I was going to do this?
I'm wondering why you felt the need to, Parizhskaya. I realize that no job is too small for you...
Other than boiler maintenance.

Fields.MenuText: Okay, I asked for that one.
That probably isn't the only job where you have issues, but you know what I mean.

Fields.DialogueText: If you say so, Kapitan.
It isn't something I concede gracefully. And yes, I understand what you meant.
My apologies.
Another Comrade of the Fleet asked me something recently
... And her answer?
"It only takes one," she said, "to turn you into a frothing lunatic. More than that number misbehaving just speeds the process."
She wasn't a carrier by any chance?
How did you know?
Lucky guess. Look, approaching everything you do seriously - no matter how insignificant the task - is commendable. But this is a little overboard, Parizhskaya.
Leave the light bulb replacements to Maintenance, okay?
Da. I have this one changed at least... can you turn on the lights again?
Sure. Here goes...
*lights pop*
... Never mind, Parizhskaya.
Yes, Kapitan.
@BATTLE
Are you all right, Kapitan?
I'm fine. I just got an earful from the Chief is all.
Let me apologize on her behalf, Kapitan. It isn't easy to look at a task to complete and not have the means to do it.
There's no need to apologize, since I can sympathise with her frustration. I know it wasn't the repair ship, but at least our munition tender found us. We still need those bricks...
... But those and harsh words alone won't stop the Rusalki. Here's a letter for you, First Comrade.

Fields.MenuText: Careful the Chief doesn't hear you saying that.
You deliver the mail, Pompolit?
You've got to be kidding. Who writes letters to a battleship?

Fields.DialogueText: I won't tell her if you won't. At least Comrade Stalin would only sign the orders to have me keelhauled... that woman would give the order and toss me overboard.
I not only have the job of delivering everyone's mail, Kapitan, I have the chore of reading it for security. Thankfully, most of them are just send-more-vodka requests.
Another battleship, apparently.
Thank you, Pompa. It's from my little sister, Marat.
Why write? I would think the Belle network would be faster. Unless it's about something personal...
It is nothing like that. She just doesn't want her French to become stale from lack of use.
Now that you mention it, you are named after the Paris Commune, so I should've guessed. But I thought you said once that language isn't your strong suit, Parizhskaya.
We're in the presence of one who lies without batting an eyelash.
*frowns*
But it's not. Understanding a language is one thing, but conveying one's thoughts in it is another. I will read this later... the Neizvestniy flot approach.
@BATTLE
... There now. The trap is set.
The trap is set for what, Parizhskaya?
Kapitan. I didn't see you there, I apologize.
It's dark down here with so many lights out, so I'm not surprised. What happened, is the light bulb issue contagious or something?
In a manner of speaking. The issue isn't the bulbs themselves, but the wiring. There is a short... here. The electricians searched for it but failed, and requested my help.
*yawns*
I found it, but not without considerable effort.
It even had you hunting? That's not an easy feat.
Nyet. It's not. Which leads me to only one possible conclusion.
That is...?
Gremlins.

Fields.MenuText: ... Gremlins.
You know, Parizhskaya, if I were speaking to anyone else but you... but you're serious, aren't you?
As much as I'd love to dismiss that out of hand, there's the little fact that I'm being told this by the spirit of my ship. Still... how did you come to that answer, Parizhskaya?

Fields.DialogueText: Da.
Absolutely, Kapitan.
I understand your skepticism, Kapitan. I was doubtful too, at the start.
One of the First Comrades from Great Britain warned me of them. She said the pilots of their air force have encountered them before and were spreading the word.
Which explains the trap. What's that made of, an empty sardine tin? That mechanism is pretty clever, too.
Spasibo, Kapitan. I'm not sure how big gremlins are though, so this may be too small...
Did the Belle you were speaking to suggest it?
This is my idea. She said the way to take care of them was through regular, thorough inspections and diligent maintenance..."the constant vigilance drives them to search for greener pastures".
I don't think you have anything to worry about then, since you do all that anyway. After you get the lights restored though, go ahead and set your trap. It can't hurt.
Yes, Kapitan.
@BATTLE
That's a lot of bricks.
Yes. Enough for ten more boilers.
I know you're happy to see the repair tender, but isn't a brigade to transfer them a bit much?
This was all Grey Horse's idea.
Kommuna's?
Yes. Consider this an amusing way to demonstrate that many hands united can overcome, even against the "superior" abilities of a First Comrade.

Fields.MenuText: It still sounds pretty one-sided to me.
Won't it just demonstrate that it takes the whole ship's crew just to beat one of her? That could backfire.
And you let her talk the crew into this amusing little distraction from surveillance? This isn't port and I'd rather not be caught flat-footed over some bragging rights.

Fields.DialogueText: That would be true if she used ghost tricks and walked through decks, and if all of the bricks were easily within her reach. This an honest challenge even for her, Captain.
Not at all. We know her effort, Captain. They are measuring themselves against the hardest working First Comrade in the Fleet, so doing as much as she can is something to brag about.
Our location is not lost on me, Captain, but I wouldn't worry about this taking long..
That reminds me, Chief. This isn't the first time you've referred to Parizhskaya as Grey Horse. Do you know something that I don't?
I only know there is a saying, Captain. Put everything onto the grey horse, he'll bear anything.
That fits her to a T.
It fits her a little too well. There is another saying. One's own burden doesn't encumber.
She may not feel what she bears, but even the Grey Horse has her limits.
If you think this is overdoing it...
With this game? Even if it was, I wish you luck trying to stop her, Captain... but that isn't the issue. We may have the bricks, but until the boilers are replaced with them...
I see your point. What about the tender, do you want their help?
I'm counting on it. My people can do the work, but it isn't something we do every day. I'll take all the aid and expertise that the tender's people can provide.
*ALARM*
... Which will be none at all. Damn Neizvestniy flot.
@BATTLE
Grey Horse offered her own stockpiled vodka rations if she loses, so there is definitely more than bragging rights at stake.
Finally getting around to reading your letter, I see.
Da. I suspect I already know its contents, but Marat has done me the courtesy of writing it, so I should do her the courtesy of reading it.
I take it this isn't the first letter she's written to you.
No, Kapitan, it's not.
You don't sound happy about it.
It is... complicated. She knows me well and is writing for my sake, but if it was that simple to comply with her request, I would have done so by now.

Fields.MenuText: It sounds as if the complication is more in the how than the why, if you say she's doing this for your own good. If there's anything I can do to help...
"Complicated" sounds like an understatement. That said, I encourage you to find a solution. I wouldn't want you to have any regrets.
I never thought I'd be saying this to my ship, but no one is allowed to let family matters distract them from their part in our job out here. That includes you.

Fields.DialogueText: I appreciate your concern, Kapitan.
We take it for granted until it's gone. You are wise, Kapitan. I will take your words to heart.
I understand, Kapitan. I will work hard to resolve this and prevent it from interfering with my duties.
Carry on then, Parizhskaya.
My gentle sister, Paris Commune...
Little sister...
@BATTLE
Not that I mind it when we stop, but I notice we are stopped while at sea.
Since most of our Rusalki hunting involves a great deal of rushing around, I wonder what trouble we have run into this time.
No trouble, just a longer procedure than most.
I fail to understand.
Parizhskaya doesn't have a catapult, so for reconnaissance flights we have to stop and lower her planes into the water.
And if she had one of those?
We'd only need to stop in order to pick them up.
And is there a good reason why she doesn't have at least one catapult, if not one for each of those canvas covered crates of hers?
It was decided that I could do without the one they came with. Krasnyi Kavkaz has it now.
Typical.
I do not mind. I'm sure she puts it to very good use and I... well, I was the test ship for it.
*yawns*
I was hard on the equipment.
That was a while ago, Parizhskaya. It's too bad there's so few... it would be nice for you to have one again, to maintain your link.
Link?
My KR-1s may belong to me, but I can only sense them from the time they leave me until the time they land.
So you go blind just dropping them into the sea. Then what good are they?
Once airborne, the pilots can bring them in close enough for me to re-establish my connection.

Fields.MenuText: It may not be efficient, but it still works.
Meaning the wings that Parizhskaya's pilots wear aren't just for show.
I hear there's a betting pool set up every time a plane goes out for where the thing hits us if "close enough" winds up being in negative numbers.

Fields.DialogueText: That sounds like our official motto, Kapitan.
I hope not. I'd prefer it if my naval insignia was the only thing that was just for show around here.
A properly Russian way of saying good luck like that actually puts me at ease, Kapitan. It means those pilots will never hit us, just to spite the pool.
The first one is turning for its pass. If you will excuse me...
I am again reminded the First Comrade is a spirit and not a turret-carrying, sleep-deprived woman.
Agreed. This is about the only time I know of that she isn't solid.
Kapitan, the plane is climbing and already I can sense the Neizvestniy flot.
Time to move, then.
@BATTLE
Is something wrong with that plane, Parizhskaya? You're frowning.
Kapitan! My apologies if I have misled you. No, number seven has nothing new.
... Nothing new doesn't sound good, Parizhskaya.
It's no secret, Kapitan. Number two and number seven have been problematic from day one. Leaky hulls, heavier than designed... so many issues.
Their saving grace is that they're simple, I guess. Wood and canvas may be primitive by today's standards, but at least it only takes a good woodshop to keep them in the air.
A good thing, too. If Heinkel had no shame delivering such a poor product originally, what could I expect from replacement parts?
Wait... Heinkel? Your flying boats are German made?
You could say that. ... Though given all the repairs and replacements over the years, very little of them can still be called German made.
They are known as Heinkel HD-55s, in certain circles. Korabelniy Razvedchik-1 is good enough for me, however.
And I imagine you picked up German from them. You know, to go along with the rest of the languages you don't consider yourself good at...
*frowns*
Why would I know German from my flying boats, Kapitan? They don't talk.
Right. Silly me.
*yawns*
... I picked up the little German I know from the engineers who installed the catapult I once had. I can hold a conversation about stress tolerances and drag coefficients, but not much more.

Fields.MenuText: Most people would consider humble battleship to be an oxymoron, Parizhskaya. In your case, it fits.
There are Germans who couldn't hold a conversation in German on those things, Parizhskaya!
I have to agree with the Pompolit on this one, Parizhskaya. You know far more than you give yourself credit.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Kapitan! I take being a member of the Workers' and Peasants' Red Fleet seriously.
I see. There are a number of German Comrades of the Fleet that I don't understand, though. But if you say so...
Self-praise is no praise.
Kapitan, you were saying earlier that you thought it would be nice if I had a catapult again. I was wondering what you meant by that.
Just wishing out loud, I guess. Why? You wouldn't want one again?
I wouldn't want to deprive the ship who owns it now.
That isn't the only catapult in the world, Parizhskaya. What about a more recent model? It might not be specific to your KR-1s, but...
That would be an option. I'd be concerned about the stress on them, though.
Well, what about replacing them? You just said yourself how bad they've been.
*frowns*
Da... and I still have them because their replacements are worse. I'm waiting to see the replacement's replacement.
@BATTLE
Has Parizhskaya arrived yet?
Just now.
It's not the worst injury I've seen her receive, so you can relax.

Fields.MenuText: That she's hurt at all worries me. She hasn't had an accident like this in a while.
That's good to hear. I'm still worried about her pride right about now though... the workshop is one of her favorite places.
I'll relax when I'm good and ready to, Pompolit.

Fields.DialogueText: That's true, Kapitan, but remember: accidents still happen. A well-rested First Comrade just means fewer accidents. It doesn't eliminate them.
She was in a workshop, Kapitan, not a china shop. If neither she nor the shop and its other occupants are in pieces, her gaff is nothing more than fodder for sailor's yarns.
Absolutely, Kapitan. My hope is that you're good and ready before she sees you and blames herself for your state.
Kapitan! There was no need for you to visit the Infirmary over my little mishap...
Parizhskaya, all I was told was that you'd broken something and were en route to the Infirmary. Looks like someone exaggerated, though - you don't look too worse for the wear.
No, that was accurate. I broke a lathe.
Well, that doesn't sound so bad...
First Comrade...
I was... across the room, in the process of cutting new braces when I broke it.
It sounds like you're going to need to re-earn your workshop license then, Parizhskaya.
Da, Kapitan.
@BATTLE
It can still be fixed, however.
Parizhskaya, what's going on?
It's all wrong! Very wrong!
Calm down and explain it to me. What's wrong?
Kapitan, my bow! It's gone!
... Parizhskaya-
But that's not the worst of it, Kapitan. I'm going backwards!
I can feel my turbines and shafts turning as they should, but I am not making any headway!

Fields.MenuText: I think I can safely say I know where your bow went.
Thank you for bringing it to my attention, Parizhskaya. Rest assured, we'll find your missing bow and right our course.
Are you drunk?

Fields.DialogueText: I knew you would have the answer, Kapitan. Where is it? Do we need to go back for it?
You can, Kapitan? Because if we don't find my bow before we return to port, the gremlins will get away and sell it on the Black Market!
Kapitan? Of course not. Why would you think that?
Your bow is where it always has been, Parizhskaya... this is your stern.
My stern? Yes... yes, this is my stern. How did I-
Kapitan, Neizvestniy flot approaching.
From what direction?
Port... Starboard.
Which one?
... Both?
@BATTLE
For now, I'd like you to follow me to Sick Bay for a check-up.
You don't have to worry about that.
First of all, your face is red. Second, your ensign is right there on the flagstaff.
I came as soon... damn it!
That's putting it mildly...
It's not that bad...
So, what do you think it is?
What I think...? Why would my thoughts matter, Captain? Wouldn't a doctor be more appropriate?
Unfortunately, no. Parizhskaya has been in here often enough for cuts and bruises that they have a baseline for her, but the temperature she has is beyond human.
But our head of Medical services is convinced she's not sick. Not with a bacteria or virus, anyway...
I could have told you that.
Really?
So, what is it then, oh comrade doctor of the mechanical?
Heat exhaustion bordering on heat stroke. I'd be a poor leader of the Engineering spaces if I didn't know the signs and my people dropped like flies over it.
But I haven't been below decks.... I think...
Maybe not, but your boilers still are.
You think a mechanical issue is affecting Parizhskaya?
You asked for my thoughts, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: How would something this serious get past her?
That's the craziest thing I've ever heard.
Say you're right, Chief. Even if I give the order now, It takes time to cool them down. That doesn't solve her immediate condition.

Fields.DialogueText: I just don't know. Unless she's been stoically silent when she should have been reporting her problems?
*shrugs*
That doesn't solve her immediate condition.
Right. So, how do we get her cooled off?
Get her down to her telnyashka. Cold compresses. An ice bath, or-
No ice bath.
... Kapitan, no ice bath, please...
... Or you could return to your hull, First Comrade.
What?
The Comrades of the Fleet aren't the only ones who talk amongst themselves, and I get a lot of raised eyebrows at the amount of time Grey Horse here is corporeal.
... I guess an ice bath will work...
What about a fire hose instead? It's messier, but they're meant to be set up and used right away, yes?
A fire hose is good. I can use it to help with fire control, just in case.
Just in case? Why...
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
... I might have been experiencing a little heartburn, lately...
About as crazy as a ship mistaking her tail for her nose?
If I'm right, the boilers are the long term solution. In the meantime, I'd suggest the more aggressive means to get Grey Horse's temperature down.
I'm sorry, Parizhskaya. I know you didn't want the ice bath, but...
*yawns*
There's no need to apologize, Kapitan. If anyone should apologize, it should be me. Chief Dimitrieff has enough to do without catering to my whims.
An ice water reservoir and recirculating pump is hardly a "whim." It was also your idea... she just had what you wanted rounded up and assembled.
It was? I don't remember.
I'm not surprised. It didn't take a doctor's degree to know you were delirious.
... I didn't... say anything, did I?

Fields.MenuText: Enough to realize the Ice Cruise isn't the sole cause of your fear at being icebound ever again.
Not unless you consider your request for wood and your carving knife something you shouldn't have. Really, Parizhskaya... a flying boat model just to take a bath?
Other than the directions to make an ice bath without ice in the bath, not a thing.

Fields.DialogueText: I see. I'd like to say it is more a healthy respect rather than a fear, but that would ring hollow about now.
Would you believe that it is to practice release and recovery in heavy sea conditions?
This is why I don't drink to excess, Kapitan. Wine causes guilt.
So, what happens now, Kapitan?
What do you mean?
I can tell that we aren't moving and only a fraction of my boilers are even warm, but we're still out to sea.
Yes. Until you and the Chief can tell me the boilers are all ready, we're not going anywhere.
But what about our patrol?
We got in touch with the other Protection Force ships in the area and came up with a new, temporary plan... we're pretending to be crippled, to act as bait.
But, Kapitan, with so many of my boilers cold I am...
Pretending to be crippled. Pretending is courageous, while actually being in trouble - especially trouble not related to combat - is sloppy. That could attract some harsh criticism.
Chief Dimitrieff warned me from the start and she and her sailors have done their best, but if word of this gets out...
More than her position may be jeopardized. And not only hers.
Exactly. So what happens now is that on the surface we act like a sitting duck. Underneath however, we paddle like mad.
... We will need to paddle more than that, Kapitan. It seems the Neizvestniy flot consider me attractive bait.
@BATTLE
Either way, I will work to ensure that my performance is unaffected, should the situation arise.
The situation won't arise, not if I have anything to say about it. One Kronstadt is all the Kronstadts you get, Parizhskaya.
You wanted me to visit, Parizhskaya?
Mne zhal'! I apologize, Kapitan. But the doctor says I haven't been released to return to duty yet. What does that mean? My temperature has returned to normal.
You're not feverish, no. But until I know why it happened in the first place, I want you to cool your heels.
But I thought Chief Dmitrieff had determined the cause to be my boilers, Kapitan.

Fields.MenuText: The boilers were a symptom of a deeper issue, Parizhskaya.
Which you didn't notice were tap dancing on the limits of safety. If you're too preoccupied to notice a problem until it's close to blowing up in your face, you belong here.
And not all of them are rebricked yet. Help me understand how this happened, Parizhskaya. I don't want to see you have a relapse.

Fields.DialogueText: A deeper issue? I don't understand.
My apologies, Kapitan.
I have worried you. ... I am sorry for that, Kapitan.
Can you think of anything on your mind that distracted you from catching the warning signs?
... I suppose there is something...
*ALARM*
Hold that thought, then, and consider yourself on temporary duty.
Da, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
*knock*
Parizhskaya? You in there?
Da. Right where I'm supposed to be!

Fields.MenuText: Parizhskaya, is this your idea of a protest? Thanks to your bandoneon practice, the crew is comparing sick bay to a gulag.
They tell me the food in sick bay is awful, so I come bearing lunch.
Are you decent? I hear you've been back in the ice bath.

Fields.DialogueText: Not at all, Kapitan. But improvement only comes with practice... I've even managed to go from the anguished cries of a hugged goose to resident bellows player!
It is not so bad, but that plate of makaroni po-flotski is still a welcome sight. Thank you.
Yes, Kapitan. If my boilers affected me, the reverse might also be true so I've tried to do my part for their temperature control.
So, any idea of what has you so distracted lately?
Da, I believe so. Kapitan, do you remember the letter I received from Marat? It had... bad news.
It sounds like it had terrible news if it's impacting you this much, Parizhskaya. Can you talk about it?
Da. Most of it is common knowledge. First, I feel I must explain... Marat isn't my only little sister. I have two others: Frunze and Oktyabrskaya Revolutsia.
Oktabrina is as feisty as ever and doesn't need doting from her older sister. Frunze...
Marat's letter was to encourage me to make my peace with Frunze.
I'm sorry. Was she attacked? I haven't read any reports that suggested she's been involved in major operations or-
She was not attacked, Kapitan. Not how you mean. But we're about to be.
Oh, damn.
I really am sorry, Parizhskaya. We'll talk later.
@BATTLE
Parizhskaya, I thought I once heard you say that all of your sisters were still active.
My apologies if I gave you the wrong idea, Kapitan... I said they are all still in service. They are not equally active, however.
Frunze has not been to sea since 1918.
That's over two decades, Parizhskaya. I'm still confused. Why is Marat saying that she's in trouble now, after all that time? Did something happen recently?
Da. Back then, Frunze had an accident and ended up requiring repairs. Since then she's had some... but not enough.
*smiles proudly*
But she is patient, that little sister of mine. And optimistic. Every work-stoppage, every cancelled project has been merely a minor setback to her.
Even when her turrets were removed, she was brave about it... she was sure it was so that she could receive bigger, more state-of-the-art guns.

Fields.MenuText: She's a battleship, all right...
They landed her turrets? That doesn't sound good.
Sounds more like a brave face, to keep you three from worrying.

Fields.DialogueText: She would be pleased to hear you say that, I'm sure.
Perhaps not, Kapitan. I always held onto the hope that as long as they weren't used as replacements for anyone else, there was still a chance they could be returned to her.
Then it was for my sake, Kapitan... I was prepared for transfer to the Black Sea Fleet only a year or so after that. It's been about ten years since.
Are her turrets still in storage, or... ?
From what I know, only half of them are. Two were put on a train east and that's the last anyone heard about them. As soon as she was able, Marat did research about that.
And?
She won't tell me, but says that she has told Frunze.
Then, if Frunze isn't worried about it...
Marat's research turned up another piece of news that she did share with me in her letter: the latest plans for Frunze included converting our sister into a floating battery.
So she wouldn't be mobile, but she could at least fire big guns again. ... Except you said included. Past tense.
Da. I lifted my voice and guns against the Majority, dishonored my name... and the Party modernized me and made me the Flagship of the Black Sea Fleet.
My little sister did nothing wrong, had an accident and twenty years later isn't even worth upgrading to a battery hulk.
Why, Kapitan? Why?!
Feeling a little better now?
*yawns*
A little. I must thank everyone again for my blanket, it is a gift beyond measure.
They know. You have no idea the number of pictures they've taken of you napping with your quilt.
I see. Should I be worried?
Not unless you're worried about being compared to a bear hibernating in her den. You and those casemates of yours...
I find them comfortable. I also have enough of them that my sleep spot won't interfere with a cleaning detail's work.
You could also... how did the Chief put it? Return to your hull?
It is an option, true. I prefer not to exercise it, but if you want me to...
I'm not asking you to, I'm just curious why you don't.
Perhaps because I am the only one on board who can, and I don't want to appear superior to my fellow comrades.
You are also a Belle, Parizhskaya... and from each according to his or her ability...
Well, perhaps it's also because there is something so satisfying about being able to lend an actual hand to my crew that I don't wish to waste a single moment able to do so.
Perhaps it is because as I am, my crew is able to see and interact with me. They can acknowledge my existence. I fear that if I returned to my hull for too long, I would be forgotten.
There's little chance of that, Parizhskaya.
I suppose so.
Is there you're concerned you won't be able to materialize again?
I have no fear of that when I'm wide awake, Kapitan.

Fields.MenuText: Probably because you're awake when you're trying to remember, rather than half asleep like you were when you did it. I'm certain that if you were that sleepy, it would come back to you.
The means might be a bit drastic, but if you ever go missing for longer than a day or two, I'll order you back to yourself.
When you put it that way, it does sound risky. And since I'd rather be in charge of a ship with a Belle...

Fields.DialogueText: The only problem is that in order to remember, I'm so sleepy that I drift off before I can take notes for my awake self to read.
That may still be easier said than done even as a command, but I appreciate the gesture, Kapitan.
I will continue my current resting habits, then.
I'm still not sure why you want to remember that first time so badly... unless you're looking for insight on how to help someone else do it too...
@BATTLE
... But I was half asleep when I did it that first time, and no matter how I wrack my brain, I can't remember the details.
Parizhskaya, you're not seriously trying to figure out how to help make Frunze a Belle....
Well... yes, Kapitan. The thought has occurred to me that if Frunze were to become a First Comrade, the Party would consider her important and valuable enough to make battleworthy again.
Does Marat know about this?
Yes. She will not help me by sharing what she remembers though... she says that even if I succeeded, that is not a solution to Frunze's problem.
I think I understand why. Remember what the Pompolit said, Parizhskaya. You're a powerful ship with a blemished history that chose her own captain. But you are still a powerful ship.
If Frunze were a Belle, she'd be a Belle with no guns to defend herself and no propulsion to escape. They'd take her apart to find out how Belles tick.
Soviet engineers wouldn't be the only ones who would if the opportunity presented itself, Kapitan.

Fields.MenuText: But you agree they would.
Maybe so, but other engineers wouldn't dissect her and praise her afterwards as a martyr to the Cause.
I know. It's why I didn't say anything about what flag they salute, Parizhskaya. Unless the Protection Force got hold of her first, she'd be at risk of that no matter where she went.

Fields.DialogueText: She'd also be beholden to whoever modernized her. ... I ran from the wolf but ran into a bear.
... So what would you have me do, Kapitan? Look the other way while my sister is condemned to scrap?
Let Frunze be herself, Parizhskaya. You said she is patient, so let her decide what to do with that patience.
Does she accept the small part she has been given with grace and leave the stage with dignity, or does she stay quiet until she thinks the time is right? Either way, it will be her choice.
I... I... hadn't thought... when put that way, I understand. You are right, Kapitan. She is still a battleship... and I'm a fool.
Just a doting big sister. So, what will you do now?
I'm not sure. Marat is encouraging me to write to Frunze. She's been writing the letters to me to set an example.
Even though Frunze isn't a Belle?
"It's the thought that counts," is what Marat tells me.
She has a point. Oh, and let me know where Frunze's located, Parizhskaya, so we can schedule a visit if we get the chance.
I'm sure she'd like that, Kapitan. Spasibo.
@BATTLE
It's good to see you in better spirits, Parizhskaya.
I'll second that. How's your arm?
My arm?
Your shoulder was bandaged. I assumed that the good doctors in Sick Bay had seen enough of your cuts and scrapes to mend that right...
*yawns*
Ah, that. It was just a covering. I am fine.
Then what was the bandage about?
The tattoo I have there is a relic of who I once was. The Party has allowed me to keep it as a memento, but I am forbidden to display it.

Fields.MenuText: Even if I gave you permission? You have me curious now...
That sounds rather cruel to me.
If it's that big a reminder, why not get rid of it?

Fields.DialogueText: I appreciate the sentiment, Kapitan. But yes, even if you gave your blessing I would not. It does not belong to me, not anymore.
It would be more cruel for the ship that will one day use my old name to be confused with me, Kapitan.
I probably will, one day... the Siege of Sevastopol is too honorable an example of Russian tenacity and grit for my old name to lie fallow for long.
Now, if you will excuse me... I may be limited to light duty, but my work approaches.
That sounds more like your flying termite nests, to me.
*smiles proudly*
Call them what you will, Pompa, but they still fly.
@BATTLE
Not as cruel as it is for a battleship to be confused with a salvage and repair ship. Trust me, I almost reported to the wrong vessel because of it.
Now, now, Pompa. I can think of worse ships than Kommuna to be confused with.
When Sevastopol is launched, I will gladly have it removed for her. In the meantime, it does no harm.
I hear Chief oversaw your re-introduction to the workshop, Parizhskaya.
She did. She had me test the repairs on the lathe by turning something.
Which I'm sure you passed with flying colors. So what did you make? Anything special?
It was nothing of importance, Kapitan. Just a toy cannon.
That's surprising. May I see it?
If you'd like.
For a toy, that's not light. What's it made of?
Bronze. I melted a stack of coins into a rod and turned that.

Fields.MenuText: That's quite the metaphor.
I won't ask if you can actually fire it, then.
It probably would have been cheaper to buy a rod with the coins, but that wouldn't have been nearly as satisfying for you, I'm sure.

Fields.DialogueText: Where money speaks, there the conscience is silent.
Nyet. That would be a miniature cannon rather than a toy one, and my guns are more than sufficient.
You know me well, Kapitan. Da, it was very enjoyable that way.
So, what's next? Will you be making a carriage for it?
I wasn't intending to. This is just a demonstration piece, to show Chief Dimitrieff that I can work safely in the shop. Nothing more.
This is too detailed to be just a demonstration piece, Parizhskaya. You should be proud of your skill... why not show it off?
But it's just a toy, Kapitan. An ornament with no purpose. That's too bourgeois, for my taste.
Even if that "ornament" is art or has sentimental value? But that's all right, Parizhskaya, we'll do this your way.
Kapitan?
Can you hand me one of the shells on your bandolier for a moment?
Da, of course. Here you are.
Thank you. Now then...*ahem*... First Comrade Parizhskaya Kommuna, what is this I see? You have an empty pocket on your bandolier!
Kapitan? But you just...
It looks unprofessional, First Comrade. It is as noticeable as a missing tooth. Fortunately, I have just the thing to fill that empty pocket: this cannon replica.
I see. Well, then... Comrade Kapitan! My apologies on the sub-standard state of my appearance!
You are absolutely correct. I am a representative of the Workers' and Peasants' Red Fleet to the world. Unprofessionalism on my part reflects poorly on my comrades, my home and myself.
Well said. Then here is your Bandolier Pocket Device. Wear it with pride, and we will speak no more of this oversight.
Yes, Comrade Kapitan!
*smiles*
... Now, may I have my spare shell back, Kapitan?
Certainly. I take it you'll return it to munitions storage?
I may not have to, if an opportunity to use it on the Neizvestniy flot I have detected presents itself...
@BATTLE
... Here.
Kapitan, do you know anything about my gremlin trap?
I know you made one, but other than that... no. Why?
It's missing. I think the gremlins took it.

Fields.MenuText: Not this again...
You're sure you didn't misplace it?
Diabolical. I guess you'll just have to combat them with thorough inspections and diligent maintenance after all, then.

Fields.DialogueText: Kapitan?
I'm sure of it. See? I made a map and maintenance log, so Chief Dimitrieff could assign an inspector while I was in the Infirmary.
Don't worry, Kapitan, this is just a minor setback. I will use what I have learned so the next generation of gremlin traps I make will not be as easy to steal.
So you can't sense it anywhere, like you can with other pieces of your equipment?
... I hadn't thought of it as equipment before, but I guess I could try to concentrate on it... but that will have to wait, however.
I do not want to divert my focus from the Neizvestniy flot I just found.
@BATTLE
Parizhskaya, what are you doing with that empty paint can?
I'm designing another gremlin trap, Kapitan.
So you weren't able to find the first one, I take it.
Actually, I did. You were right, Kapitan! Once I thought of it as special equipment, I was able to locate it.
The gremlins had stored it in a rats nest that I wasn't aware of before, so it turned out to be a good thing they took it!
Not bad, Parizhskaya. But if it was that effective in finding where the "gremlins" stash things, why are you making another one?
Because it won't work for ships without a First Comrade, Kapitan.
Good point. If you don't mind the suggestion, Parizhskaya, once you have made a better gremlin trap, send one to Frunze.
A letter to her may be a thoughtful gesture, but if you ask me, a trap from the fleet's resident gremlin expert shows you care.
I wouldn't go so far as to consider myself a gremlin expert, but I think that's a wonderful idea. Thank you, Kapitan.
Never mind.
Parizhskaya?
You look like there's something you want to say...
I... da. Kapitan, may I make a course request?

Fields.MenuText: Certainly, Parizhskaya. Request away.
For you to do something as rare as request a specific course, it must be important to you. If it's in my power, consider it done, Parizhskaya.
You can request anything you want, Paizhskaya, but I make no guarantees I'll accept it.

Fields.DialogueText: Spasibo.
Any course that has me keeping the Neizvestniy flot at bay is good enough for me, but I'm afraid I have unfinished business.
I understand.
I was wondering if we could stop by our nearest port.
Is Comrade Kommuna interested in the report on her bicycle repairs?
I would be lying if I said I wasn't a little curious concerning the results, but...
I know, I'm just teasing you a little. You never finished your story to them, did you?
Nyet. And considering nothing is guaranteed in times of war... I'd like the chance to finish the story, if at all possible.
I understand, Parizhskaya. Let's do something about ending your intermission.
Thank you, Kapitan.
@BATTLE
Kapitan! You've arrived at last! Here you go...
A shot glass? What's the occasion?
For one, it's to celebrate our successful overhaul of the boilers and end of stationary target duty.
That's two, Comrade. The third is to the crews' narrow, but victorious win in their struggle against the First Comrade.
... And since she is the one pouring, any other toasts after that will be at her discretion.
I thought the brick loading contest was called on account of Morgana interference.
Not so, Kapitan, I lost fair and square. Besides, I have more than enough to share.

Fields.MenuText: Correct me if I'm wrong, Parizhskaya, but it takes more than hoarded daily rations to have this much vodka.
There are better reasons for you to reward your crew than that, Parizhskaya. But if your honor requires using the contest as a reason to break out the vodka, then so be it.
Then break out the pickles, canned beef and rye and get this celebration started already!

Fields.DialogueText: Da, Kapitan. I also acquire extra where and when I can for equipment sterilization, backup anesthetic purposes, and barter. It's also a proper gift in certain circles...
Know sense, do not make debts. This is a small price to pay, Kapitan.
Right away, Kapitan!
I sense the Neizvestniy flot. Kapitan...
Since the toast is poured, I'll help you make this quick
To thrashing the Morganas who have interrupted this celebration. May we put her on the bottom before Parizhskaya's vodka gets warm!
Your health!
Cheers!
@BATTLE
This was sure to happen. If you will hand me that tray please, I'll start to collect the glasses.
There will be other opportunities.
I suppose. I was hoping to make a toast with everyone, though.
Oh? What to?
To Frunze. You are right, Kapitan... just as the proletariat could not be handed their freedom, I cannot cut her keys. This is her struggle, not mine.
That does not stop me from wishing her happiness, however... and I thought, if I could provide her the collective wishes from my whole crew...
Why not do a practice toast, then? That bottle over there isn't completely empty...
A practice? So that I know what I want to say beforehand?
Exactly.
... All right... here. Let's see... ah...
F-Frunze has always marched to the beat of a different drum... she insisted on being the one to run the speed trials for our family, like a cavalier on the fields before Poltava.
That's not to say she objects being given her revolutionary name, though... even isolated as we were in the reserve fleet, we knew of General Frunze's leadership.
Because of all that, I can only guess what her intentions are... or how I can give her my support for them. But I'm confident they correspond to the highest ideals of the Revolution.
... So I will drink to Frunze and her success. ... And I ask that you do the same.
It's a good toast, Parizhskaya. Cheers.
I thought you cleaned in here earlier, Parizhskaya.
I did, Kapitan. I didn't think you would mind if I borrowed your desk, to compose my reply to Marat.
Not at all. But... is there a reason why you're using a carpenter's pencil?
It's sturdy, lasts a long time and doesn't roll off the deck when I put it down. I'm so used to a carpenter's pencil in my grip that it feels odd when I use anything else.
I'm sure it makes your handwriting unique.
Feel free to use something a bit more permanent in the desk, Parizhskaya. I doubt you would give Petrenko a reason to censor you, but pencil is a bit easier to alter...
Pompa wouldn't censor me, Kapitan. ... He doesn't know French, so I assist him with that detail for the mail of the international members of the crew...
... I suspect that isn't the only language that you assist him with...
... but I agree with you. I'm sure Marat would appreciate a letter in ink instead of lead, too. This is just a rough draft, so that I only have to make a copy.
It saves paper that way.
That reminds me...
Da?

Fields.MenuText: Your plan is to send Frunze a Non-Belle gremlin trap, right? I recommend you send a copy to your other sister as well, so she doesn't feel like she's being left out.
Whatever you've been doing to keep my typewriter ribbon going all this time has been a lifesaver that I didn't even know I needed. Thank you, Parizhskaya.
Next time, don't use old copies of Pravda to make the posted weather report. It looked like a ransom note.

Fields.DialogueText: One for Oktyabrskaya Revolyutsiya? Yes, I agree. She's the only active battleship for the Red Fleet now, while Marat and I are engaging the Neizvestniy flot... a big responsibility.
There's no need to thank me, Kapitan... anyone could re-ink a ribbon, I'm sure.
It was smooth on paper, but they forgot about the ravines. I'll keep that in mind for next time, then.
Good luck with your wordsmithing, Parizhskaya.
(leaves)
Let's see now... My dearest Marat... let me know of what you think of the instructions for making your own gremlin cache locator. If they're acceptable...
The kapitan and I have talked at length... thanks to my kapitan....
... I hope the three of us can spend time together, Marat. I love...
Love? Je suis tombé amoureux avec mon capitaine?
I suppose I have.
That is not for her to learn in a letter, though...
I look forward to speaking with you, the next time we meet. ... Your loving older sister, Parizhskaya Kommuna.
Providing her protection from gremlins is the least I can do for her.
Did I hear somebody moving around in here?
Parizhskaya?
*ALARM*
I guess not.
@BATTLE
